TITLE: Sam Bankman-Fried, Crypto Billionaire, Wants Washington to Follow His Lead
SUMMARY: Sam Bankman-Fried is a studiously disheveled billionaire who made a fortune overseeing trades that are too risky for the U.S. market. Now he wants Washington to follow his lead.

TITLE: How Do Higher Interest Rates Bring Down Inflation?
SUMMARY: Our columnist is responding to readers’ questions. This week, he focuses on inflation, with the help of a bond maven and a Nobel laureate.

TITLE: ‘Another Unequal Burden’: Working with Long Covid
SUMMARY: Some research has shown that lingering Covid symptoms are more prevalent in people in their 30s and 40s — when workers are often in the prime of their careers. How will companies support employees with debilitating symptoms that can linger for months or even years after infection?

TITLE: Jack Cakebread, Pioneering Napa Valley Winemaker, Dies at 92
SUMMARY: He was an auto mechanic with a sideline in photography when he and his wife bought a cattle farm in 1972. They turned it into one of America’s leading wineries.

TITLE: India Bans Most Wheat Exports, Adding to Fears of Global Food Insecurity
SUMMARY: The ban could compound a worldwide shortfall worsened by the war in Ukraine and exacerbate an already dire forecast for global hunger.

TITLE: Will Crypto Play a Role in Funding Abortion Access?
SUMMARY: Activists and nonprofits are considering digital currencies as a way to raise funds. But can they really do anything other payment methods can’t?

TITLE: Richard C. Wald, Leader in Print and Network News, Is Dead at 92
SUMMARY: He was the last managing editor of The New York Herald Tribune. When that newspaper folded, he went on to top jobs with NBC and ABC News.

TITLE: Val Broeksmit, 46, Who Blew the Whistle on Deutsche Bank, Dies
SUMMARY: An itinerant musician, he leaked secret files to F.B.I. investigators looking at the bank’s ties to money laundering, the Trump Organization and Russia.

TITLE: The World Tries to Move Beyond Covid. China May Stand in the Way.
SUMMARY: Xi Jinping has redoubled his country’s efforts to control the virus, even as a growing number of leaders call on Beijing to change course.

TITLE: Stocks Return to Earth, With the S&P 500 Nearing a Bear Market
SUMMARY: The market has been producing double-digit returns for investors, even at moments of great national strife. But the party has ended and it may be a long time before it begins again.

TITLE: Student Loan Borrowers Don’t Deserve ‘Forgiveness.’ They Deserve an Apology.
SUMMARY: Whatever the cost of any student loan cancellation program, it’ll just be money we should have spent on higher education in the first place.

TITLE: Think Twice Before Taking Out a Private Student Loan
SUMMARY: Interest rates are rising for both federal and private borrowers. But private loans have fewer protections and are often more expensive, student advocates say.

TITLE: Elon Musk Says His Takeover of Twitter Is ‘On Hold.’
SUMMARY: Mr. Musk said he wanted to confirm Twitter’s findings that spam and fake accounts make up less than 5 percent of its users.

TITLE: Where Did People From the Great Resignation Go? Back to Work.
SUMMARY: The Great Resignation was in fact a moment many people traded up for a better-paying gig.

TITLE: Republicans Wrongly Tie Biden Immigration Policies to Baby Formula Shortage
SUMMARY: A lawsuit settlement requires the federal government to provide water and food, including formula, to detained migrant children.

TITLE: Treasury Warns Foreign Banks Against Helping Russia Evade Sanctions
SUMMARY: Adewale Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, met privately with international financial institutions to make clear the consequences of sanctions evasion.

TITLE: California Has Record Budget Surplus as Rich Taxpayers Prosper
SUMMARY: Gov. Gavin Newsom proposes widespread cash rebates, bonuses for health care workers and free transit.

TITLE: Overlooked No More: Junichi Arai, Innovative Textile Designer
SUMMARY: His experimentations with different materials and technology earned him widespread recognition as well as patents and awards.

TITLE: An Optimist at the Helm of IBM
SUMMARY: Arvind Krishna is trying to stay in touch with the company’s roots as he confronts today’s challenges.

TITLE: Is Elon Musk Backing Away from Twitter?
SUMMARY: Some early morning tweets fed into speculation that he could back out of the deal.

TITLE: ‘Mrs. Doubtfire’ to Close on Broadway, After Reopening
SUMMARY: The musical, which shuttered temporarily in January as the Omicron variant spread, has struggled with the slow return of tourists to the theater.

TITLE: The World’s a Mess. So They’ve Stopped Saving for Tomorrow.
SUMMARY: Many adults under 35 are throwing financial caution to the wind. It’s all about saving less, spending more and pursuing passions.

TITLE: Crypto is in meltdown mode this week.
Russian Shipping Traffic Remains Strong as Sanctions Take Time to Bite
SUMMARY: The traffic was robust in March and April, reflecting the time it takes for sanctions to come into effect and an enduring profit motive for trading Russian energy.

TITLE: Dinosaur Skeleton Sells for $12.4 Million at Christie’s
SUMMARY: The remains of a Deinonychus antirrhopus, the beast that inspired the velociraptor in “Jurassic Park,” are believed to be the first of their kind sold at a public auction.

TITLE: Cryptocurrencies Melt Down in a ‘Perfect Storm’ of Fear and Panic
SUMMARY: A steep sell-off that gained momentum this week starkly illustrated the risks of the experimental and unregulated digital currencies.

TITLE: White House, Under Pressure, Says It Will Address Baby Formula Shortage
SUMMARY: Senior officials announced minor steps the administration would take to try to increase the supply of formula, even as they conceded that Americans might not see quick relief.

TITLE: Pentagon Praises a New York Times Series That Exposed Civilian Deaths in Air War
SUMMARY: “We knew that we had made mistakes; we’re trying to learn from those mistakes,” John Kirby, the Pentagon spokesman, told reporters.

TITLE: Meatpackers Misled Public and Influenced Trump Administration During Covid, Report Says
SUMMARY: A congressional report claimed that meatpacking companies issued “baseless” warnings about food shortages and influenced government decisions to keep plants open early in the pandemic.

TITLE: New Data Show Few Black Economists at the Fed
SUMMARY: The central bank has made few strides in hiring a more racially diverse staff of economics doctorates. Entry-level jobs are a different story.

TITLE: Jerome Powell Confirmed for a Second Term as Fed Chair
SUMMARY: Jerome Powell, whom the Senate confirmed to a second term on Thursday, said allowing rapid inflation to persist would be more painful.

TITLE: Two Twitter Leaders Are Leaving Company Following Musk Deal
SUMMARY: An internal memo shared with employees said the platform’s general manager and general manager for revenue would be departing.

TITLE: Troubled Student Housing Firm Would Pay Tens of Millions to Investors
SUMMARY: A $50 million agreement by Nelson Partners over a high-rise near the University of Texas may force it to sell interests in other properties.

TITLE: Wall Street Slide Continues, With S&P 500 Edging Closer to Bear Market
SUMMARY: Concerns about inflation and interest rates ignited the sell-off. But it has taken on a life of its own. Bringing inflation down will “include some pain,” the Fed chair said.

TITLE: Siemens, the German Conglomerate, Is Leaving Russia
SUMMARY: Siemens said its second-quarter earnings took a $625 million hit because of Western sanctions on Russia.

TITLE: TerraUSD’s ‘Death Spiral’ Is Raising Alarms About Investor Protection
SUMMARY: Some crypto insiders say they saw the implosion of TerraUSD coming. Other stablecoins could also run into trouble.

TITLE: After Chris Rock and Dave Chappelle Attacks, Comedy Venues Increase Security
SUMMARY: Will Smith slapped Chris Rock onstage at the Oscars. Dave Chappelle was tackled at the Hollywood Bowl. Now some venues are increasing security to protect comedians.

TITLE: F.D.A. Authorizes Underwear to Protect Against S.T.I.s During Oral Sex
SUMMARY: It’s the first time underwear has been authorized for this purpose, and it provides a new choice for protection where the few options have been unpopular.

TITLE: Britain’s economy shrinks as inflation ‘begins to bite.’
SUMMARY: Gross domestic product fell 0.1 percent in March. The risk of recession has increased as household budgets are constrained by the highest inflation rate in 30 years.

TITLE: Why Union Efforts at Starbucks Have Spread Further Than at Amazon
SUMMARY: Why has the union campaign spread so much further at the coffee chain than at the e-commerce giant?

TITLE: GM’s Mary Barra Has a Plan to Win the Electric Vehicle Race
SUMMARY: The General Motors chief says efficiencies, innovations and learning from mistakes will allow her company to become a leader in electric vehicles.

TITLE: Where Can You Still Buy a House for Less Than $150,000?
SUMMARY: A new analysis of the U.S. housing market shows that affordable homes are quickly vanishing from some cities.

TITLE: Softbank Funds Post $27 Billion Loss
SUMMARY: The Japanese conglomerate’s fortunes have sharply reversed from a record-setting result a year ago.

TITLE: Instacart Takes a Big Step Toward a Public Offering
SUMMARY: After a year of turmoil, the company said it plans to test the waters on Wall Street despite investors’ cooling on technology stocks.

TITLE: Bloomberg Aims to Compete Directly With British Press
SUMMARY: A new venture, Bloomberg UK, is the first inkling of a new international strategy for the business news giant.

TITLE: Senate Confirms Philip Jefferson as a Fed Governor
SUMMARY: Lawmakers have now confirmed three of Mr. Biden’s nominees to the seven-person Fed Board of Governors in Washington.

TITLE: Rivian shares surge after the E.V. maker affirms its 2022 production goal.
SUMMARY: The company encountered supply-chain problems and investor concern after its initial public offering last year gave it a huge market value.

TITLE: Google’s I/O Conference Offers Modest Vision of the Future
SUMMARY: Artificial intelligence is being woven into an array of the company’s products. But the change — for now — is subtle.

TITLE: Striking a Balance Between Art and Motorcycle Maintenance
SUMMARY: J. Shia, the owner of Madhouse Motors in Boston, repairs and refurbishes vintage bikes, but she also creates motorcycle sculptures shown in exhibits.

TITLE: Moderna Vaccine Provokes Strong Immune Response in Children 6 to 11
SUMMARY: Antibody levels rose in the children who received it, suggesting the vaccine protects against infection. But the data were gathered before the arrival of Omicron.

TITLE: New F.T.C. Majority Gives Lina Khan a Chance to Push an Aggressive Agenda
SUMMARY: The confirmation of a third Democrat creates an opportunity for Lina Khan, the Federal Trade Commission’s chair, to advance efforts to rein in corporate power.

TITLE: Disney+ Added 7.9 Million Subscribers Last Quarter
SUMMARY: New releases like Pixar’s “Turning Red” helped the service surpass analyst estimates for new subscribers globally.

TITLE: Lorie Logan, Fed Veteran, to Lead Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas
SUMMARY: Ms. Logan will lead a central bank district that encompasses Texas, northern Louisiana and southern New Mexico starting in August.

TITLE: Slate Names Ex-HuffPost Editor as Its New Top Editor
SUMMARY: Hillary Frey will lead the online publication as it tries to find its way after a number of high-level departures.

TITLE: Bitcoin Is Increasingly Acting Like Just Another Tech Stock
SUMMARY: The cryptocurrency’s plunging value has mirrored losses in the Nasdaq, a benchmark that’s weighted toward tech stocks.

TITLE: Lufthansa Apologizes After Jewish People Were Barred From Flight
SUMMARY: Passengers said that after landing in Germany, more than 100 people were blocked from boarding a connecting flight to Hungary, after a handful of passengers disobeyed a mask requirement.

TITLE: Nearly One-Third of Ukraine’s Jobs Are Lost Amid War, U.N. Labor Agency Says
SUMMARY: The report highlights the grim economic toll of Russia’s aggression and the challenges that lie ahead for Ukraine and other nations.

TITLE: As the war fuels inflation, Biden plans to address rising prices and global shortages.
The Pushback on E.S.G. Investing
SUMMARY: Calls to rein in investing based on environmental and social principles are growing louder.
